utterances.speaker: rep
utterances.text: Good morning everyone. Thanks for making time today to discuss what you saw in the demo last week. I know Thomas, you had some concerns about how this would fit into your current operations, and Lisa, you had some great questions about the analytics capabilities. Mark, appreciate you joining us again as well.

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: Yeah, look, I'll be direct here. I've had a week to think about this, and honestly, I'm not seeing why we need to disrupt what's working. We've been running our operations just fine for fifteen years.

utterances.speaker: prospect_digital_transformation_lead
utterances.text: Thomas, I think that's exactly why we need to have this conversation. The demo showed clear efficiency gains in production scheduling and inventory management. Those are pain points we've documented.

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: Pain points you've documented, Lisa. My team isn't complaining. We know our systems inside and out.

utterances.speaker: rep
utterances.text: Thomas, I appreciate that perspective. Can I ask, when you say things are working fine, are there any areas where you've seen delays or inefficiencies, even small ones? Sometimes those compound over time.

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: Sure, we have the occasional hiccup. Every manufacturing operation does. But we handle it. We've built workarounds, we have processes. This feels like a solution looking for a problem.

utterances.speaker: prospect_digital_transformation_lead
utterances.text: But those workarounds are manual. The demo showed we could automate at least 60% of those processes. That's time and resources we could redirect.

utterances.speaker: prospect_cfo
utterances.text: Lisa, what's the total cost of ownership over three years? You mentioned automation, but I need to understand the full financial picture before we talk about redirecting resources.

utterances.speaker: rep
utterances.text: Good question, Mark. Based on your company size and the modules Lisa was interested in, we're looking at roughly $480,000 over three years. That includes licensing, implementation, training, and support.

utterances.speaker: prospect_cfo
utterances.text: Half a million dollars. And what's the guaranteed ROI timeline?

utterances.speaker: rep
utterances.text: Most of our manufacturing clients see ROI between 18 to 24 months. It depends on adoption rate and how quickly you can phase out legacy processes.

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: Phase out legacy processes. There it is. You want us to rip out systems that work and gamble on something unproven in our environment.

utterances.speaker: prospect_digital_transformation_lead
utterances.text: It wouldn't be a rip and replace, Thomas. We discussed a phased approach in the last call, remember? Starting with one production line as a pilot.

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: Even a pilot means pulling my people off their work to learn a new system. It means risk. What happens when something breaks during implementation? We have production quotas to meet.

utterances.speaker: rep
utterances.text: That's a valid concern. Our implementation team works around your production schedule, and we maintain your legacy systems in parallel until you're comfortable with the transition. We've done this with manufacturers like Precision Metals and they kept 100% uptime during implementation.

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: Precision Metals isn't us. Every operation is different. What works for them might be a disaster here.

utterances.speaker: prospect_digital_transformation_lead
utterances.text: Thomas, can I just say something? Our competitors are modernizing. I've seen what others in our industry are doing. If we don't start making these moves, we're going to fall behind.

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: Who's falling behind? Our margins are healthy. Our customers are happy. This sounds like change for change's sake.

utterances.speaker: prospect_cfo
utterances.text: I'm with Thomas on this. If our financials are solid, why are we looking at a half-million dollar investment with a two-year payback? That's capital we could use elsewhere.

utterances.speaker: prospect_digital_transformation_lead
utterances.text: Because we're looking at today, not three years from now. The market is shifting. Digital capabilities are becoming table stakes.

utterances.speaker: rep
utterances.text: Lisa's raising an important point. I'm curious, Thomas, Mark, are you seeing any pressure from your customers for more real-time visibility into orders or production status?

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: We send weekly updates. That's been sufficient for twenty years. Nobody's complaining.

utterances.speaker: prospect_digital_transformation_lead
utterances.text: Actually, I've heard from two key accounts asking about real-time tracking. I mentioned that in my report last quarter.

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: Two accounts out of how many? We have over a hundred clients. I'm not upending our operations for two requests.

utterances.speaker: prospect_cfo
utterances.text: What about ongoing costs? That $480,000, does it include annual price increases? What are we locked into?

utterances.speaker: rep
utterances.text: The licensing fees have a maximum 3% annual increase built into the contract. You're not locked in beyond one year at a time after the initial implementation period, but most clients stay because of the value they're getting.

utterances.speaker: prospect_cfo
utterances.text: So we make this investment, and if it doesn't work out, we've spent how much before we can exit?

utterances.speaker: rep
utterances.text: The first year commitment is around $185,000. That covers implementation and the first year of licensing.

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: So nearly $200,000 before we even know if this works for us. That's a pretty expensive experiment.

utterances.speaker: prospect_digital_transformation_lead
utterances.text: It's not an experiment, it's an investment. The demo clearly showed the functionality we need. The reporting capabilities alone would save my team dozens of hours each month.

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: Your team, Lisa. What about my team? They'd need to learn entirely new workflows. Change how they've done their jobs for years. For what? So you can generate reports faster?

utterances.speaker: rep
utterances.text: The training program is pretty comprehensive. We typically schedule it over 4 to 6 weeks, and users tell us the interface is intuitive once they get past the first few days.

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: 4 to 6 weeks of reduced productivity while people learn a new system. You see what I mean? The disruption alone isn't worth it.

utterances.speaker: prospect_digital_transformation_lead
utterances.text: What about the long-term gains? We can't just think about the next six weeks. We need to think about where we want to be in five years.

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: In five years, I want to be doing what we do now, just better. Not learning some new platform that might be obsolete by then anyway.

utterances.speaker: prospect_cfo
utterances.text: Has anyone looked at CompetitorZ? I've heard they're cheaper and some people in my network have mentioned them.

utterances.speaker: rep
utterances.text: CompetitorZ is definitely less expensive upfront, that's true. The tradeoff is they don't have the manufacturing-specific modules we offer, and their support model is mostly self-service. For an enterprise your size, that can become an issue.

utterances.speaker: prospect_cfo
utterances.text: How much cheaper are we talking?

utterances.speaker: rep
utterances.text: Their base platform is probably 30 to 40% less, but you'd need to build out custom integrations for your production systems. That often closes the price gap and extends implementation time.

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: Or, here's a thought, we don't do any of this. We keep doing what works. Zero cost, zero risk, zero disruption.

utterances.speaker: prospect_digital_transformation_lead
utterances.text: That's not zero risk, Thomas. The risk is stagnation. It's losing talent who want to work with modern tools. It's losing customers to competitors who can offer better visibility and faster turnaround.

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: Show me the data on lost customers. Show me the employees leaving because of our systems. You're talking about hypothetical risks. I deal in real operations.

utterances.speaker: prospect_digital_transformation_lead
utterances.text: The data is in the market trends. Every industry report shows digital transformation is essential for manufacturing.

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: Industry reports written by consultants trying to sell services. I'm running a factory, not chasing trends.

utterances.speaker: rep
utterances.text: Thomas, I hear you saying the current state is working. Can I ask, what would need to change for you to consider that a solution like this might add value? Is there any scenario where modernization makes sense?

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: If we were failing, sure. If customers were leaving, if we couldn't meet demand, if our systems were actually broken. But none of that is happening. We've done fine without this for years, and we'll keep doing fine.

utterances.speaker: prospect_cfo
utterances.text: I have to agree with Thomas. I'm not seeing the business case for this level of investment right now. Our capital budget is already stretched with the facility expansion.

utterances.speaker: prospect_digital_transformation_lead
utterances.text: So we're just going to table this? We spent time on the demo, we've had these conversations, and we're walking away?

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: I'm not walking away from anything, Lisa. I'm protecting our operations from unnecessary risk. That's my job.

utterances.speaker: rep
utterances.text: I appreciate everyone's candor today. It sounds like the timing might not be right. Lisa, would it be helpful if I sent over some additional case studies from manufacturers who were in a similar position? No pressure, just for future reference.

utterances.speaker: prospect_digital_transformation_lead
utterances.text: Sure, that would be helpful. Though I'm not sure when we'll revisit this conversation given the reaction today.

utterances.speaker: prospect_vp_operations
utterances.text: Look, nothing personal here. I'm sure your product works for some companies. We're just not one of them. We're good where we are.

utterances.speaker: prospect_cfo
utterances.text: I need to jump to another call. Thank you for your time and the information.

utterances.speaker: rep
utterances.text: Of course. Thank you all for considering us. Lisa, I'll send those materials over, and please don't hesitate to reach out if circumstances change or if you have any questions down the road.

utterances.speaker: prospect_digital_transformation_lead
utterances.text: Thanks. I appreciate your time walking us through everything.
